author: Madeleine van Niekerk
title: JSE weakens as miners weigh amid firmer dollar environment | Markets
text:
Picture: JSE THE JSE was softer at midday on Monday as miners weighed on the local bourse due to a firm dollar and lower commodity prices.
Asian markets retreated after weak Chinese manufacturing data put pressure on markets.
Barclays Research analysts said in a global note that Asian equities fell and the dollar bounced back as China’s official manufacturing purchasing managers index fell to a five-month low of 50.
The Shanghai Composite index was down 1.11%, while the Paris CAC picked up 0.57% and the German Dax 30 added 0.69%.
At 1.03pm the JSE all share was down 0.34% at 51,876.40 and the blue-chip top 40 gave back 0.41%.
Resources and gold miners were the main losers, down 1.92% and 1.59%, respectively, amid softer commodity prices. Platinums gave back 1.48%.
Bidvest said in a weekly report the focus this week would shift to US employment issues, with the release of the Automatic Data Processing and nonfarm payrolls figures the main events.
"The recent slowdown in Chinese manufacturing activity highlights the likelihood that a fresh round of fiscal stimulus might be forthcoming," Bidvest said.
Meanwhile, a pro-government Greek newspaper reported at the weekend that Greece may seek €24bn in a first tranche of bail-out aid from international lenders in August.
Domestically, Naamsa vehicle sales would be the latest forward-looking data to gauge the strength of the domestic economy, Bidvest said.
Among individual shares on the JSE, Anglo American fell 3.86% to R153.70 and South32 was down 2.12% to R15.72. Exxaro Resources dropped 4.35% to R71.65.
Gold Fields declined 4.5% to R32.72 and Harmony dipped 1.5% to R11.82.
Anglo American Platinum was down 1.47% to R259.51 and Lonmin gave back 1.67% to R10.
